metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Callbacks
"I will call back later!"
content.html: "I will call back later!"

content.text: A callback is a function passed as an argument to another function
content.html: A callback is a function passed as an argument to another function

content.text: This technique allows a function to call another function
content.html: This technique allows a function to call another function

content.text: A callback function can run after another function has finished
content.html: A callback function can run after another function has finished

content.text: Function Sequence
JavaScript functions are executed in the sequence they are called. Not in the sequence they are defined.
content.html: JavaScript functions are executed in the sequence they are called. Not in the sequence they are defined.

content.text: This example will end up displaying "Goodbye":
content.html: This example will end up displaying "Goodbye":

content.code_html:
function myFirst() {
  myDisplayer("Hello");
}

function mySecond() {
  myDisplayer("Goodbye");
}

myFirst();
mySecond();

content.text: This example will end up displaying "Hello":
content.html: This example will end up displaying "Hello":

content.code_html:
function myFirst() {
  myDisplayer("Hello");
}

function mySecond() {
  myDisplayer("Goodbye");
}

mySecond();
myFirst();

content.text: Sequence Control
Sometimes you would like to have better control over when to execute a function.
content.html: Sometimes you would like to have better control over when to execute a function.

content.text: Suppose you want to do a calculation, and then display the result.
content.html: Suppose you want to do a calculation, and then display the result.

content.text: You could call a calculator function ( myCalculator ), save the result, and then call another function ( myDisplayer ) to display the result:
content.html: You could call a calculator function (myCalculator), save the result, and then call another function (myDisplayer) to display the result:

content.code_html:
function myDisplayer(some) {
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = some;
}

function myCalculator(num1, num2) {
  let sum = num1 + num2;
  return sum;
}

let result = myCalculator(5, 5);
myDisplayer(result);

content.text: Or, you could call a calculator function ( myCalculator ), and let the calculator function call the display function ( myDisplayer ):
content.html: Or, you could call a calculator function (myCalculator), and let the calculator function call the display function (myDisplayer):

content.code_html:
function myDisplayer(some) {
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = some;
}

function myCalculator(num1, num2) {
  let sum = num1 + num2;
  myDisplayer(sum);
}

myCalculator(5, 5);

content.text: The problem with the first example above, is that you have to call two functions to display the result.
content.html: The problem with the first example above, is that you have to call two functions to display the result.

content.text: The problem with the second example, is that you cannot prevent the calculator function from displaying the result.
content.html: The problem with the second example, is that you cannot prevent the calculator function from displaying the result.

content.text: Now it is time to bring in a callback.
content.html: Now it is time to bring in a callback.

content.text: JavaScript Callbacks
A callback is a function passed as an argument to another function.
content.html: A callback is a function passed as an argument to another function.

content.text: Using a callback, you could call the calculator function ( myCalculator ) with a callback ( myCallback ), and let the calculator function run the callback after the calculation is finished:
content.html: Using a callback, you could call the calculator function (myCalculator) with a callback (myCallback), and let the calculator function run the callback after the calculation is finished:

content.code_html:
function myDisplayer(some) {
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = some;
}

function myCalculator(num1, num2, myCallback) {
  let sum = num1 + num2;
  myCallback(sum);
}

myCalculator(5, 5, myDisplayer);

content.text: In the example above, myDisplayer is a called a callback function .
content.html: In the example above, myDisplayer is a called a callback function.

content.text: It is passed to myCalculator() as an argument .
content.html: It is passed to myCalculator() as an argument.

content.text: Note
When you pass a function as an argument, remember not to use parenthesis.
content.html: When you pass a function as an argument, remember not to use parenthesis.

content.text: Right: myCalculator(5, 5, myDisplayer);
content.html: Right: myCalculator(5, 5, myDisplayer);

content.text: Wrong: myCalculator(5, 5, myDisplayer()) ;
content.html: Wrong: myCalculator(5, 5, myDisplayer());

content.code_html:
// Create an Array
 const myNumbers = [4, 1, -20, -7, 5, 9, -6];

// Call removeNeg with a callback
 const posNumbers = removeNeg(myNumbers, (x) => x >= 0);

// Display Result
 document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = posNumbers;

// Keep only positive numbers
 function removeNeg(numbers, callback) {
  const myArray = [];
  for (const x of numbers) {
    if (callback(x)) {
      myArray.push(x);
    }
  }
  return myArray;
}

content.text: In the example above, (x) => x >= 0 is a callback function .
content.html: In the example above, (x) => x >= 0 is a callback function.

content.text: It is passed to removeNeg() as an argument .
content.html: It is passed to removeNeg() as an argument.

content.text: When to Use a Callback?
The examples above are not very exciting.
content.html: The examples above are not very exciting.

content.text: They are simplified to teach you the callback syntax.
content.html: They are simplified to teach you the callback syntax.

content.text: Where callbacks really shine are in asynchronous functions, where one function has to wait for another function (like waiting for a file to load).
content.html: Where callbacks really shine are in asynchronous functions, where one function has to wait for another function (like waiting for a file to load).

content.text: Asynchronous functions are covered in the next chapter.
content.html: Asynchronous functions are covered in the next chapter.
